senses.de: A choice that you make about something after thinking about it
senses.ex: The decision to start a family is a big one.

Tips.title: Life Choices
Tips.description: Used when referring to significant decisions about personal life or career paths.
Tips.example: Her decision to become a nurse was influenced by her desire to help others.

Tips.title: Deliberation Required
Tips.description: Implies careful thought before making a decision.
Tips.example: After much deliberation, his decision was to enroll at the university.

senses.ex: We are making decisions based on the information we have.

Tips.title: Informed Choices
Tips.description: Highlights decisions made based on available information and analysis.
Tips.example: The company's decision to expand overseas was data-driven.

Tips.title: Objective Assessment
Tips.description: Involves a conclusion without personal feelings or biases.
Tips.example: The jury's decision was supposed to be based on facts alone.

senses.de: The action of deciding something or settling a question
senses.ex: The decision to go ahead with the project was made by the board.

Tips.title: Academic Setting
Tips.description: Often found in scholarly discussions about research and analysis.
Tips.example: The decision point in the experiment determined the research path.

Tips.title: Corporate Resolution
Tips.description: Refers to decisions made by businesses or organizations.
Tips.example: The board's decision will affect the future of the company.

senses.de: The ability or tendency to make decisions quickly
senses.ex: I admire his decision when dealing with difficult problems.

Tips.title: Quick Thinking
Tips.description: Describes a person's swift response to a situation requiring a choice.
Tips.example: His quick decision saved the project from failure.

Tips.title: Under Pressure
Tips.description: Relates to making a tough decision during stressful circumstances.
Tips.example: Despite the pressure, she showed great decision in the emergency.

senses.de: A legal judgment, such as the outcome of a case or a court order
senses.ex: The court's decision is final and binding.

Tips.title: Legal Authority
Tips.description: Involves rulings or judgments made in a court of law.
Tips.example: The judge's decision will determine the outcome of the case.

Tips.title: Binding Outcome
Tips.description: Denotes a decision in a legal context that must be followed.
Tips.example: The tribunal's decision is binding on both parties.

Choice.wordDefinition:
Choice refers to the act of selecting from two or more options. It means that there are multiple possibilities, and one must pick the one they prefer.

For instance, when you are given a menu at a restaurant, you have a choice to select from various dishes.

The term decision entails making a firm choice between multiple options. It means that there are various possibilities, and one must select one and settle for it.

A choice is selecting between alternatives, while a decision involves determining and committing to one alternative.

Conclusion.wordDefinition:
A conclusion is the end result or final thought reached after considering all of the facts or evidence.

It is often used in writing, such as in a conclusion paragraph at the end of an essay.

A conclusion is the end result of considering information, while a decision is a choice made after contemplating options.

Determination.wordDefinition:
Determination refers to the attitude or mindset of being firm and dedicated towards achieving a goal despite difficulties and obstacles.

For example, a determined athlete who trains hard and perseveres despite setbacks is said to have determination.

Decision is about choosing between options, while determination is about having a strong will to achieve a goal.

Election.wordDefinition:
An election is when people vote to choose someone or something. For example, when people vote for the President of the United States, they are participating in an election.

A decision is a personal choice, while an election is a collective choice made by a group of people.

Judgement.wordDefinition:
Judgement refers to the process of forming an opinion or coming to a conclusion based on observation, experience, or knowledge.

It could also mean the ability to make sound decisions or choices. For instance, a teacher may use judgement to determine the most effective way to teach a particular lesson; or a manager might be praised for his/her judgement in handling a difficult situation at work.

Decision is a choice made from available options, while judgement is the ability or process used to make that choice.

Option.wordDefinition:
A decision is a choice that has been made after considering different options. An option is one of the choices available to make a decision.

In other words, a decision is the final choice that has been made, whereas an option is one of the alternatives that was considered before making the final decision.

For example, if you were trying to decide what to have for dinner, your options might include pizza, pasta, or salad. Once you choose pizza, that is your decision.

In summary, options are the alternatives you have when making a decision, and decisions are the final choices that have been made.

Resolution.wordDefinition:
A resolution is a determination to do something or achieve a specific goal. It is a promise to oneself or others to follow through on a chosen course of action.

A decision is a one-time choice, while a resolution is a commitment towards a long-term goal. Decisions are applicable in situations where one needs to choose between two or more options, while resolutions are applicable in situations where one wants to achieve or change something in their life.

Selection.wordDefinition:
Selection is more about making a choice based on a specific set of criteria or preferences.

Selections are usually simpler and more immediate choices, and they're often based on personal preferences rather than objective facts.

A decision involves carefully weighing different options and selecting the best one based on logic and facts, whereas a selection involves choosing from among several options based on personal preferences or specific criteria.

Verdict.wordDefinition:
Decision refers to a choice that is made after considering different options, while verdict refers to the final decision made by a judge or jury in a legal case.

In a legal case, a verdict is the final decision made by a judge or jury after all evidence has been presented and arguments have been heard.

For example, a verdict of guilty or not guilty would be the final decision made in a criminal case.

A decision is a choice made after considering options, while a verdict is the final decision made in a legal case.

Will.wordDefinition:
Decisions are applicable in situations where you need to make a choice, such as selecting a college, choosing a career path, or deciding what to eat for dinner.

Will refers to the desire or determination to do something. It is the mental state of knowing what you want to achieve and being committed to making it happen.

Willpower is applicable in situations where you need to overcome obstacles or achieve a goal, such as sticking to a diet, exercising regularly, or studying for exams.

A decision is about choosing between options, while will is about taking action to achieve a desired outcome.

quotes.Text: I'm never certain of a performance - my own or the other actors' - or the script or anything... But to me it seems there's only one place in the world the camera can be, and the decision usually comes immediately.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Orson Welles

quotes.Text: When you know what pain is, and when you have to make a choice, you learn that it is a decision. People think it's a fairytale thing, love and happiness, but you have to work hard. And then - you feel it deeply.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Mary J. Blige

quotes.Text: At the end of the day, when it comes time to make that decision, as president, all you have to guide you are your values, and your vision, and the life experiences that make you who you are.
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Michelle Obama

quotes.Text: Presidents quickly realize that while a single act might destroy the world they live in, no one single decision can make life suddenly better or can turn history around for the good.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Lyndon B. Johnson

quotes.Text: Strong managers who make tough decisions to cut jobs provide the only true job security in today's world. Weak managers are the problem. Weak managers destroy jobs.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jack Welch

quotes.Text: I did not direct my life. I didn't design it. I never made decisions. Things always came up and made them for me. That's what life is.
quotes.Title: American Psychologist
quotes.Name: B. F. Skinner

quotes.Text: I think it makes sense to believe in God, but exactly what decision in your life you make differently because of it, I don't know.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bill Gates

quotes.Text: I think that the day a justice forgets that each decision comes at a cost to someone, then I think you start losing your humanity.
quotes.Title: American Judge
quotes.Name: Sonia Sotomayor

quotes.Text: All my life, whenever it comes time to make a decision, I make it and forget about it.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Harry S Truman

quotes.Text: It is only in our decisions that we are important.
quotes.Title: French Philosopher
quotes.Name: Jean-Paul Sartre
